Name: frenchstudies/étudesfrançaises
Notes:
Students should contact an advisor if having difficulty selecting a course suitable to their level of competence. The Department of French Studies reserves the right to refuse admission to, and/or credit for, any of its language courses to a student who has, in the view of the Department, a level of competence unsuited to that course.
Students may not be enrolled in two first-year French courses at the same time; they will be denied credit for all lower-level, first-year French courses taken during that term and will only receive credit for the highest-level course.
Students may not backtrack to a lower-year language course after having taken a higher-level one (i.e., students who have completed FR 251 and/or 252 may not go back and later enrol in FR 192B, 192A, 152, 151, or 101).
Students with XX transferred university credits in French (e.g., FR 1XX) or who haven't taken French for more than three years must consult the Department before enrolling in any French courses.
Basic placement rules:
        
No previous experience in French: FR 101
Elementary and Grade 9 core: FR 151
Grade 10 core: FR 151
Grade 11 core: FR 152
Grade 12 core or 4U: FR 192A
Grade 12 extended and immersion French: FR 192B
Francophone students and students having graduated from a French high school must have the written permission of the Department to enrol in any French courses.
Students may enrol in courses for which they have secondary school antirequisites only with the written permission of the Department.

Courses.Name: Beginner French
Courses.Desc: An intensive beginner course for students with no prior knowledge of French. Emphasizes listening, reading, writing, and oral communication skills.
Courses.Notes: [Note: Not open to students who have previously taken a French course.]
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: FR 151, FR 152, FR 192A, FR 192B; advanced, near-native, or native ability in French

Courses.Name: Basic French 1
Courses.Desc: For students with some elementary or secondary school French not exceeding Year Two (Grade 10 in Ontario) or equivalent. Emphasizes comprehension, grammar, and basic speaking skills.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: One of FR 101, Ontario Grade 9 or 10 French.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: FR 152, FR 192A, FR 192B; Ontario Grade 11 French, Ontario Grade 12 French, 4U Core French, high school Immersion or Extended French; advanced, near-native, or native ability in French

Courses.Name: Basic French 2
Courses.Desc: For students with some elementary or secondary school French, not exceeding Year Three (Grade 11 in Ontario) or equivalent. Emphasizes comprehension, grammar, and basic speaking skills.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: FR 151 or Ontario Grade 11 French.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: FR 192A, FR 192B; Ontario Grade 12 French, 4U Core French, high school Immersion or Extended French; advanced, near-native, or native ability in French

Courses.Name: French Language 1: Module 1
Courses.Desc: An intensive French Language course. Vocabulary enrichment and development of reading, writing, and oral expression.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: One of FR 152, Ontario Grade 12 French, 4U Core French.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: FR 192B; High school Immersion or Extended French; near-native, or native ability in French

Courses.Name: French Language 1: Module 2
Courses.Desc: An intensive French Language course. Vocabulary enrichment and development of reading, writing, and oral expression.
Courses.Prereqs: Prereq: High school Immersion French or Extended French or FR 192A.
Courses.Antireqs: Antireq: Near-native or native ability in French.

Courses.Name: Introduction to Phonetics of French
Courses.Desc: An introduction to the structure of the French sound system with a view to improving pronunciation. Careful attention will be paid to the individual student's difficulties.

Courses.Name: Intermediate Spoken French
Courses.Desc: A course intended to develop the oral and aural skills.

Courses.Name: French Language 2: Module 1
Courses.Desc: Intensive work on grammar and written French.

Courses.Name: French Language 2: Module 2
Courses.Desc: Intensive work on grammar and written French.

Courses.Name: Business French 1
Courses.Desc: A French language course designed to enable the student to carry on standard business practice in spoken and written French.

Courses.Name: Introduction to Literature: Quebec and French Canada
Courses.Desc: A study of selected contemporary literary works of French Canada.

Courses.Name: French Civilization 1
Courses.Desc: This course traces the cultural development of France from its origin to the French Revolution. Emphasis is given to the study of music, art, architecture, literature, ideas, and daily life in their historical context.

Courses.Name: French Civilization 2
Courses.Desc: This course completes the study of the cultural development of France from the French Revolution to the present.

Courses.Name: French Culture & Literature: Origins to 1715
Courses.Desc: A survey of French culture and literature from their origins to 1715.

Courses.Name: French Culture & Literature: 1715 to the Present
Courses.Desc: A survey of French culture and literature from 1715 to the present.

Courses.Name: Introduction to Linguistics
Courses.Desc: An introduction to the basic principles of linguistic analysis (as opposed to traditional grammar) applied to the sounds, vocabulary and sentence structure of contemporary standard French and certain features of current Canadian French. Students' language learning needs will be an important feature of the course.

Courses.Name: 17th-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of 17th-century French literature.

Courses.Name: 18th-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of 18th-century French literature.

Courses.Name: French Language 3
Courses.Desc: Intensive development of writing skills through a study of stylistics and advanced composition.

Courses.Name: Introduction to Translation
Courses.Desc: Introduction to the theories and practices of French-English/English-French translation.

Courses.Name: 19th-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of 19th-century French literature.

Courses.Name: Business French 2
Courses.Desc: A French language course designed to enhance written and oral expression through the study of economic and business topics in the social and economic contexts of Canada and France.

Courses.Name: 20th-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of 20th-century French literature.

Courses.Name: French Theatre
Courses.Desc: A study of selected plays in French.

Courses.Name: 21st-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of 21st-century French literature.

Courses.Name: Languages in Contact: The History of French-English Bilingualism
Courses.Desc: This course will examine, from a historical and sociolinguistic perspective, the long-standing rivalry of our country's two official languages, the origins of their relationship, and the socio-political and linguistic implications of bilingualism.

Courses.Name: Quebec Literature
Courses.Desc: A study of selected texts by modern French-Canadian authors.

Courses.Name: Independent Cultural Study
Courses.Desc: An independent study course, in which the student chooses an area of French life on which to make a detailed study (topic must be approved by the department). A written cultural studies report is submitted, on which the student is examined orally.

Courses.Name: Advanced Translation
Courses.Desc: Intensive development of advanced comparative stylistics, translation, and composition skills.

Courses.Name: Topics in Linguistics
Courses.Desc: A study of selected topics in linguistics. Topics will be chosen by the professor according to their area of specialization.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

Courses.Name: Medieval French Literature
Courses.Desc: An introduction to French literature of the Middle Ages through the study of representative texts.

Courses.Name: 16th-Century French Literature
Courses.Desc: A focused study of a particular theme of Renaissance (1500-1600) writing.

Courses.Name: Advanced French Language
Courses.Desc: Intensive study of French composition, style, and grammar.

Courses.Name: Francophone Literatures in Canada
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of a selected genre or aspect of French-Canadian literature.

Courses.Name: Aspects of French Canada
Courses.Desc: A presentation of traditional and contemporary French Canada in the fields of the arts, literature, music, politics, and society.

Courses.Name: Children's Literature in French
Courses.Desc: A detailed study of selected aspects of French and French-Canadian children's literature.

Courses.Name: French Women Writers
Courses.Desc: A study of selected works by women writers in France from the Middle Ages to the 21st-century. The course will focus on the literary features of these works and on their value as reflections of the position of women in French society throughout the period.

Courses.Name: Topics in French and Francophone Cultural Studies
Courses.Desc: A study of selected topics in French and Francophone cultural studies. Topics will be chosen by the professor according to their area of specialization.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

Courses.Name: African and Caribbean French Literature
Courses.Desc: A detailed survey of selected Francophone writers from outside Europe and Canada.

Courses.Name: Senior Tutorials
Courses.Desc: A small group of students follows a course of study under the supervision of a faculty member. For details, inquire with the department.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]

Courses.Name: Senior Tutorials
Courses.Desc: A small group of students follows a course of study under the supervision of a faculty member. For details, inquire with the department.
Courses.Notes: [Note: This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of three times.]
